findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop transactions for all users, excluding addresses in the `allowedTransfer` mapping, which is managed by the contract owner. The owner may take advantage of it by setting the `publicSaleStartDate` to a very high value.

findings.title: ROA - Redundant Ownership Assignment
findings.description: The contract has a redundant ownership assignment in the constructor, which increases deployment gas cost and introduces unnecessary complexity to the contract code.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: UMFO - Unnecessary Mint Function Override
findings.description: The contract overrides the `_mint` function to enforce a supply cap, but this complexity is unnecessary since minting operations are confined to the initial deployment phase and respect the predefined cap.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide's naming conventions, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Local scope variable shadowing occurs when a local variable with the same name as a variable in an outer scope is declared within a function or code block.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
